comments.commentBody:
Despite check pains, I received a letter from my "insurer" questioning the need for an EKG and demanding further proof that the test was needed.

And their puppets in congress have the gall to cry "death panels."

How can it be that France makes it work? They have one of the best systems in the world,  no individual ever would go bankrupt paying for health care. The US by contrast has one of the worst systems, and all risk is on the individual, while insurers are obscenely profitable. Sounds like single-payer is good and very regulated or eliminated insurers.

I went to English 276 and a kid - student was waiving his cellphone around. I asked, and he was playing baseball with his motion of the cellphone being the pitches.
What am I saying? Just different confusion than in some of my law classes and accounting classes. Atty, CPA, age 69, OSU age 60 free program.

Americans deserve this. We are uneducated greedy louts and do not deserve proper health care. The older I get the more disgusted I become from the actions of my greedy fellow americans. What will it take for us to realize that we can not continue for profit health care alongside medicaid and medicare. Single payor for all!

Insurance companies are just robber barons in very thin disguise.  I almost never used my insurance with Anthem BCBS, have no pre-existing conditions, take no meds and stay healthy....the rates went up each year because I had an individual policy and am self-employed.  Thank God I turned 65 the year they upped my premium to almost $650 and I could tell them to take a hike.  One of my daughters has no insurance - refuses to give it to those thieves.  I just pray she never gets sick, but at least she can save her money.  I threw away tens of thousands...
Really no question that, as a TV personality has said, the US has become a country Of, By, and For the Corporations. And even worse they are many of them now offshore corporations!
The only industry that gets away with NOT providing a service they've been paid for. So much for letting the market regulate itself.
Great comments from a lot of thoughtful people! Single Payer Now! Call France and ask them to set up their system here!

Yes, we live in a country that drives families into financial ruin / bankruptcy if they are unlucky enough to fall ill. It's absolutely disgusting. Meanwhile, our elected officials have gold-plated health benefits, as do all federal employees. And don't forget Tricare for the military. Most Americans - those not employed by federal or state gov't or not in the military - pay significantly more each year for fewer benefits and fewer choices. Just two years ago my job offered 7 different plans for enrollment; this year there were two choices - both UHC and both beyond crappy.

And of course our piddly raises (which we can't complain about because aren't we so lucky to still have a job?) don't even begin to compensate for the massive increase in inflation. So I'll assume that most readers are like my family and your standard of living in 2011 is worse than in 2001.

Our government allows for-profit businesses to ration healthcare. It's absurd. It's evil. The fact that so many of our fellow citizens are brainwashed into supporting the current system is - frankly, it's too depressing to think about. I guess all of us can just cross our fingers and hope we don't get sick. Because if we do, we can't afford treatment. Hey, maybe we'll skip the house payment to pay medical bills and then the banks can foreclose on us! Welcome to America.

GREED MARCHES ON!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Insurance companies and oil companies, two of a kind and both are protected by the Republicans against the people.

They keep making lame excuses why they have to charge more but the reality is they're just greedy!

I am self-employed 60-yr-old widow.
Aetna charges me $1,932.00 per month--for one person!
This is bankrupting me.
Should be illegal/unconstitutional.
It is cruel and inhumane.

I'll wager that the ultimate blame for upward spiraling costs is the insurance industry itself. For instance, doctors and hospitals must employ workers to manage claims, file paperwork and track patients as they move through the insurance conveyor belt. Those salaries are passed on as fees to patients, etc.

It's a sick system, not fixable. What should we folks do about it? We're waiting for sleazy politicians to fix it, but it's clear that won't happen. So short of getting out the pitchforks and torches, can we collectively change this?

Folks are more careful when they're spending their own money.  Nothing surprising about that.  Perhaps this is the way to rein in medical costs.  The all-you-can-eat-at-no-cost-to-you systems don't work.

Parasites. We don't need Health Insurance. We just need Health Care. The Health Insurance Parasites and their Republican Lobby-slators have put themselves BETWEEN us and the care we all require, set themselves up as gatekeepers to exploit the voting citizens who elected them but pay them only a fraction of what their Corporate Employers do.

Disgusting.

Republican Predatory Capitalistic HealthCare is one of the most destructive forces in America. 85% of our working people will have to file for bankruptcy during their working lives.

The GOP is an unGodly sham.

"This article makes me angry. I am a healthcare provider in many insurance networks"#9
Shelley, actually you should be grateful to your own AMA which has successfully killed any attempt to become "sane" in this country.

This is all I know: My 93-year-old mother, diagnosed with dementia, is currently in a nursing home (receiving Medicaid, her personal finances having been depleted a number of years ago). I am her 59-year-old daughter, working full-time while traveling back and forth to the nursing facility each day to ensure that she receives adequate nutrition. My last conversation with her doctor can be summarized thusly: Since my mother has "no quality of life" (even though she recognizes me, knows my name, and can reminisce about her life from about 1920 to 1935), I should let her aspirate her food, induce pneumonia, put her into hospice care, and let her die. I don't know whether his attitude comes from many years of dealing with elderly patients (where the inevitable outcome is death--be it sooner or later), or whether it comes from the steady insinuations from politicians and insurance companies that the elderly are a drain on resources. All I know is that it stinks that someone who, along with her late husband, worked hard to achieve a middle-class American life, should be treated like a burden--while insurance companies rake in the dough. My mother always voted Democrat, my father voted Republican, and I've been an Independent. Given my recent hard-earned experience: never, EVER, will I vote for a Republican for as long as I can make it to the polls.

Free enterprise at its finest. Privatization, deregulation, tax reduction. Milton Friedman would be proud of how his mantra has been so taken to heart. The GOP certainly doesn't hesitate to take credit. If you're too poor to pay for your health care, it's your own fault and you deserve to die. Social Darwinism at work. Is this a great country or what?

The state of health care in this country is shameful. It's long past time for single-payor national health care. No other industrialized nation with western values treats its citizens with such callous disdain. Others see what is happening here and they recognize the "American Dream" is pure corporate propaganda. We're becoming a nation of serfs.

You'd think that given the title of the piece there might actually be some reporting on actual profits. Where are the numbers for specific companies. I'm sure It's true, but are we just supposed to take your word for it?

"The situation in the United States is Social Darwinism, pure and simple. The poor will die and the rich will live"#57
Correct. Our Democratic governor, for example, spends his days throwing out the elderly and disabled from their homes in a hope that this will bring him Presidency.
Pretty obvious a single payer system provides the most services at the best price.  If we give it a name like "America's Self Funded Health Insurance Plan" it wouldn't be called socialism?

They take the money now but will be hurting in the long run. I pay the full $14,500 a year premiums for my health care. There's nothing left of my pay to actually use the insurance but when I do I pay out of pocket until my deductible $500 is met. Then I pay 20% until $2500 is met. What's going to happen in the near future is people who can't afford the go to the Dr. will need catastrophic health care that will cost the insurance companies way more money than if they offered affordable premiums where people could get the care they need before it gets out of control. Insurance cost will climb to where less people can afford insurance and those companies will just choke themselves out of business. Our government sees people living longer so they want to keep raising the retirement age. Sure people are living longer, they had affordable heath care in the past. I'll be lucky to get to age 60 with what hand I'm being dealt.

What these uber-capitalistic right-wingers don't see is that insurance is not the true product. A check-up, and operation, medicine.. these are the products of the industry. Insurance is intended to level costs, thus is essentially a means of financing. When has for-profit financing ever reduced the cost of a purchase? It's a 20-30% surcharge we pay for "choice", which amounts to an array of coverages, exclusions, and deductibles designed to be confusing and sound better than it is.

The most efficient healthcare systems in the world are single-payer. Only the ideologically blinded argue otherwise.

The insurance companies have hijacked healthcare in this company and intimidated our government out of providing what every other civilized nation has: free universal health care.  They are corporations like any other, and they are as disgusting.  Why is anyone surprised?

Here is what I propose: Let the American people decide, put it to a nation wide vote. "Do you want a single payer system run by the government, based on the medicare model. No involvement with insurance companies." I bet that vote would pass by a landslide. I you could ever get it on a ballot.
